intro: Lycopodium scariosum var. decurrens, commonly known as the creeping clubmoss, is a low-growing evergreen plant native to parts of Asia and North America. It belongs to the family Lycopodiaceae and is characterized by its slender, prostrate stems that form dense mats. The plant produces small, spirally arranged leaves and has spore-bearing structures called strobila at the tips of its branches. It thrives in moist, shaded environments such as forests and rocky areas. Its unique morphology and ecological role make it an important component of its native habitats.
